article.title: The evaporation valley in the Kepler planets

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main difference between the analytical model and the MESA numerical models shown in Figure 1?
choices: The analytical model predicts a much shorter mass-loss timescale for all envelope mass fractions.
The analytical model does not account for the impact of self-gravity at large envelope masses.
The MESA models do not show a peak in mass-loss timescale for low-mass planets.
The MESA models predict a much wider range of mass-loss timescales for a given envelope mass fraction.

multiple_choice_question.text: According to Figure 2, what happens to planets with initial envelope mass fractions below X2?
choices: They are herded towards an envelope mass fraction of X ~ 1%.
They retain their initial envelope mass fractions over time.
Their envelope mass fractions decrease slowly and steadily over time.
They are stripped of their envelopes, leaving behind a bare core.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following factors does NOT significantly affect the envelope mass fraction (X2) at which a planet\'s radius doubles?
choices: The orbital period of the planet.
The density of the planet\'s core.
The mass of the planet\'s host star.

multiple_choice_question.text: Equation 20 describes the mass-loss timescale (tx) for a planet\'s envelope.  What does this equation predict about the timescale for planets with envelope mass fractions greater than X2?
choices: The timescale will be longer than 100 Myrs.
The timescale will be shorter than for planets with envelope mass fractions less than X2.
The timescale will be independent of the planet\'s orbital period.
The timescale will be primarily determined by the planet\'s core luminosity.
